cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/vnx/adapt.message: NIT: if you update PS then consider removing this.

IIUC the LUN(volume) failed to delete since it had a temp snap,
shouldn't we delete the temp snap before deleting the LUN?

Imaging that we have volume V1 and it's snapshot S1, and we create new volume V2 from S1. A temp internal (user-invisible) snapshot S2 is created by copying S1 during V2 creation. Both S1 and S2 are snapshots of V1 while S2 with name `tmp-snap-V2`. Then we delete V1, the deletion will be delayed due to it still has snapshot S2. Then the migration finishes and we delete V2, V2 will be deleted on line 787 and S2 will be deleted on line 806. Then the delay deletion of V1 will complete. So, there is no volume left on VNX.

contrib/rackspace/heat_keystoneclient_v2.message: This one appears to be have been intentional

I guess it depends on what you consider the purpose of assigning names to loggers.

Is it so that people wanting to debug a particular file can immediately guess which logger to change the configuration for? In that case __name__ is good, and allows you to move the code around without having to modify it.

Or is it so that people who have custom log-level configs set up will not find them getting broken all the time? In that case __name__ is very bad whenever code moves around.

I think the answer is 'a little of both'.

Sort of. I think it was actually intended to be heat.common.heat_keystoneclient back when this corresponded to the code in heat.common.heat_keystoneclient. Not that it should have used the same logger even then, because that makes things very confusing for someone trying to debug. And then that code moved but this wasn't updated (see https://github.com/openstack/heat/commit/1d02822c0fb26188d12ae947dbe355d303c7e731), either. So it's clearly wrong.

Worth noting: if it had used __name__ to begin with, as it should have, none of the code moves above would have mattered here at all.

nova/tests/spy.py.message:
interesting idea. :) 

It is almost like everything we need. The caller can assert calls on the mock. But not transitively. Like _mock.return_value.another_call will not work as _mock.return_value never returned to the system under test so functions are never called on that.

Still I think this allows the caller not to store call args manually in the before / after spy methods, but still assert them at the end. Which is good.

I might not call this parameter a 'mock' as this cannot be used to change the behavior of the function we are spying on. E.g. setting _mock.return_value does not do anything.

On the other hand using _mock.side_effect in the before / after spy calls can effect the execution. E.g. _mock.side_effect=ValueError() will cause the the _spy() wrapper raise the ValueError at L26. This might what the author of the before / after wanted. So meh. 

I guess my only issue is that some things work on _mock (asserting calls, raising with the use of side_effect) while others (transitive calls, return_value) does not work. So wee need to document the behavior carefully.
All good points, gibi. I'll rename and document accordingly.

Since you specify boot_index=0 in the boot requeist, the instance has two devices with boot_index==0, one is autocreated from an image (or is a root volume of the volume-backed image), other is yours blank.

Nova checks bdms for uniquenes of non-negative boot_indexes. If any non-negative boot_index is duplicated it raises InvalidBDMBootSequence. This must occur for any kind of second volume, not only for blank one.

So if that check doesn't work properly in some case, the fix should don't have custom checks for source or destination types.

This is definitely an API behavior change. I'm not sure it's something that we should allow, but do we know that this fails the server creation later in the hypervisor?

Reading this:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/block-device-mapping.html

"boot_index - Defines the order in which a hypervisor will try devices when attempting to boot the guest from storage. Each device which is capable of being used as boot device should be given a unique boot index, starting from 0 in ascending order. Some hypervisors may not support booting from multiple devices, so will only consider the device with boot index of 0. Some hypervisors will support booting from multiple devices, but only if they are of different types - eg a disk and CD-ROM. Setting a negative value or None indicates that the device should not be used for booting. The simplest usage is to set it to 0 for the boot device and leave it as None for any other devices."

Seems to suggest the validity of this combination is hypervisor-specific, which we can't know about in the API at this point.

I'm going to -1 this until some other people can take a look, or you can definitively say this doesn't work with any of the virt drivers that nova supports in-tree.

Yeah, I'm not 100% sure how to parse that doc. It says some hypervisors may only support one boot device and that 0 always means "use for booting." So it seems like a blank volume even in that case would be invalid.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: not sure about that. I mean this is wired up as the "openstack overcloud status" command so the created/updated might be useful/necessary info

Well, AFAIU 'overcloud status' command is meant to check the current deployment status.

Unless the user wants to know (using this command) when config download was last run (started and finished), though updated timestamp is misleading (same as created) until the execution finishes, IMO, we don't need these timestamps.

Also every deployment creates a new mistral execution. Therefore the old timestamps don't exist when a new deployment is started (which is not possible until the old one is finished).

I would possibly agree that changing the cli/user interface behavior (right or wrong) is something we should avoid. 

If we still think that 'overcloud status' was meant to provide additional information (other than the status i.e deploying/deployed), we could change the workbook to include these timestamps along with execution_id/root_execution_id.

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: this needs to be abstracted into oslo.db enginefacade and also needs to internally consult the dialect-level flag, never CONF.database so that functions remain agnostic of a specific configuration.
I'll take a look at adding this functionality next after next week.

this is why we use facades!   context_manager.writer.savepoint.xyz is all part of oslo.db.   

A quick way to make the savepoint not happen is to just disable it based on the "ndb" flag here: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L930 

However, in this particular block, and others that use savepoints, it's not really safe to get a DBDuplicateError - the ORM rolls back the enclosing transaction when this occurs, which is not what's wanted here.     so even though we can hit this in enginefacade very easily, it might not be the correct approach considering what we expect a savepoint block to do.

In the case of NDB, we perhaps want to either make a whole different session / connection / transaction in parallel to the one going on here, or we would want to disable the savepoint below the level of the ORM, so that the ORM follows along with savepoint semantics and doesn't rollback the transaction.

Which leads to how that would be done.    We'd just stick some more event handlers in oslo_db.sqlalchemy.ndb to intercept the savepoint instruction at the execution level, and just have them ignored.   That is, we just block savepoints completely.   (If we had our "ndb+pymysql" dialect, that would be even easier).    That would again be a "before_execute()" or "before_cursor_execute()" event handler that just intercepts savepoints, either looking for objects like expression.SavepointClause or for strings like "^SAVEPOINT .*" and rewrites them as do-nothings.

ndb would need to be able to continue to commit a transaction in which an integrity error was just emitted.   Some databases can't do that.
Hi Mike. Do you have examples on how to intercept savepoints and disable them from oslo_db? I don't see any examples of this. I agree, it would be ideal to move that logic into our ndb module.
... namely here.  if we didn't do a savepoint, it's not safe to retry this operation.   a retry will fail because the whole enclosing transaction will have been rolled back.
I'll work on disabling this after next week.
needs to be abstracted into enginefacade

I figured adding the keyword arguments would add some clarity to what we're passing to context and also prevent oddities if other arguments are added in different positions to the method signature (which should protect callers from breaking).

I'm fine with this change, Lance. ++

Others may object to the closing paren on its own newline, though (even if I personally prefer this code style). Just a word of warning :)

This will likely get expanded if/when the openstack-spec merges [0], which should yield:

  self.default_roles ['admin', 'member', 'auditor']

Then for each role + scope pair, we essentially have a persona to exercise (e.g. modeling a situation where Jane has role admin on the system, Alice has role member on the system, Bob has role auditor on the system, Steve has role admin on a project, etc.)

If anyone has ideas for how to make sure these tests stay DRY, I'm all ears. I tinkered with expanding out those roles locally, and I essentially came up with what you see below, where each test case exercises a persona. Conversely, they could be structured to be:

  def test_system_admin_can_execute_os_admin_password(self):
      ...

But I feel that might result in a test explosion.

Thoughts?

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523973/

I'm not a huge fan of DRY'ing up tests. I feel being explicit (if wordy) about the fixtures being utilized in a test makes the test easier to read and understand, especially years after the test was originally written.

That's totally understandable and I agree with that perspective. As I work through a few more of these, I keep them structured the way they are at the cost of modifying data structures in several tests when we add new policies.

I suppose we can always change it later to reduce duplication.
Interesting. From looking at the oslo.context patch you linked in the Depends-On, I would have expected the system kwarg to oslo_context.RequestContext to be a boolean value, not a dict?

Good question. When we originally designed it, we envisioned it being a boolean. We changed it in later patches because we felt a dictionary was more appropriate and allowed for more flexibility in the future.

Context can associate to project IDs and domain IDs, which are pretty specific. With system-scope we can make it a boolean, but that kind of prevents us from elaborating on system scope in the future. For example, today you can get a token scoped to "system: {'all': True}", but in the future we could enhance keystone to expose the entries of the service catalog in such a way that allowed users to scope to parts of the system. Or allow administrators to grant authorization to a part of the overall system (e.g. you could give me a role on the identity portion of the system, only allowing me to do identity management).

We're pretty far from that today, but it seemed like it would be useful to leave the implementation open to moving in that direction if we wanted to in the future. We're hoping the current dict representation allows for that.

Oh. I guess that's not the issue. The issue is that the XML gets created with something like

 <size>4192256.0</size>
 <align>2048.0</align>

instead of

 <size>4192256</size>
 <align>2048</align>

In that case, this test is unfortunately not useful, because mock's assert_called* methods compare the operands for equality, and 2048.0 == 2048.

What would be better is a test that goes all the way to producing the actual XML so you can assert that the text values don't have the decimal.

dcdbsync/db/identity/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: Why did you make this change?

> Why did you make this change?

sqlalchemy will try to do transactions in parallel and cache contents in the thread local structure. If a read transaction is on going and write transaction is invoked, it will complain "Can't upgrade a READER transaction to a WRITTER mid-transaction", and "Command Out of Sync". So I changed for reader and writer to use different thread local.

The exact errors like these:
=========================================
2019-06-24 19:51:58.584 3600194 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity     self._writer()
2019-06-24 19:51:58.584 3600194 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py", line 711, in _writer
2019-06-24 19:51:58.584 3600194 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity     "Can't upgrade a READER transaction "
2019-06-24 19:51:58.584 3600194 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity TypeError: Can't upgrade a READER transaction to a WRITER mid-transaction
2019-06-24 19:51:58.584 3600194 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity
......

2019-06-24 20:00:59.413 3600193 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity     self._read_ok_packet()
2019-06-24 20:00:59.413 3600193 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 398, in _read_ok_packet
2019-06-24 20:00:59.413 3600193 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity     raise err.OperationalError(2014, "Command Out of Sync")
2019-06-24 20:00:59.413 3600193 ERROR dcdbsync.api.controllers.v1.identity.identity DBConnectionError: (pymysql.err.OperationalError) (2014, 'Command Out of Sync')

"If a read transaction is on going and write transaction is invoked, it will complain "Can't upgrade a READER transaction to a WRITTER mid-transaction", and "Command Out of Sync". "

this is not really accurate, sqlalchemy does nothing "in parallel", it's the application running that would be using threads or greenlets and runs code concurrently.  a threadlocal is used to compartmenatalize state between different threads.

the error noted it emitted by oslo.db when a function that uses the enginefacade.reader() context manager calls another one that tries to do enginefacade.writer().   this is normally a code structural issue and has nothing to do with concurrency (note that nothing in Python is parallel due to the GIL).

however, since you are also getting "commands out of sync" that suggests the program is possibly, though not necessarily, having an actual concurrency problem.   that would be a deeper issue that needs to be reproducible and analyzed.   the out of sync error might also be possible if a connection is in an error state that the driver isn't handling well.

Looks to me like you have changed this to create a new threading.local for every single transaction. That doesn't seem right.
Also, how could the same thread be doing both a read and write transaction at the same time?

I think Bart is right, we don't want to make this change.

Either the read transaction needs to be closed and a new writer one opened, or the entire block needs to be writer (which is likely less efficient, so we likely dont want that)

take a look at the traceback and see what operations it is attempting.
yes this is definitely wrong, this would have every function using a new connection / transaction even if one calls the other.

> yes this is definitely wrong, this would have every function using
 > a new connection / transaction even if one calls the other.

I'm using pecan as the framework for REST call handling, with each of the API functions in this file (eg. user_get()) corresponds to a REST call. And in each of the read API functions here I use "with get_read_connection as conn". So is it that all the db calls within the with block shares the same connection and this thread.local object? 

Now the problem by using _CONTEXT is that it's somehow shared by multiple REST call handing, and in parallel causing READER to WRITTER upgrade issue etc. So a new thread.local and new connection per REST call doesn't seem to be very bad. Otherwise, maybe the REST calls have to be handles in sequence.

> So is it that all the db calls within the with block shares the same connection and this thread.local object? 

the idea is that once you say "with enginefacade.reader.connection:", everything that is called *within* that block will also use the so-called "reader" connection.  if you call a method that uses "writer" it will fail; because this means that your "reader" method is in fact writing data to the database (because it is calling down to a function that writes).  If you want to explicitly have a writer function use a different connection in this case, it can call enginefacade.independent.writer().

> Now the problem by using _CONTEXT is that it's somehow shared by multiple REST call handing,

that's what a threadlocal variable is for.  You only use one if it is in fact shared by multiple threads or greenlets at once.   The functions that use it will see attributes that are local to their current thread or greenlet.  Note that if you are using eventlet, it is *ESSENTIAL* that your program has called the eventlet monkeypatching functions *BEFORE* this threading local has been created, otherwise it will not work correctly.

> and in parallel causing READER to WRITTER upgrade issue etc. 

that is not possible, assuming the threading.local() is working correctly (e.g. needs monkeypatch if greenlets are in use) because the enginefacade will look for attributes on this object and it can only see attributes that are local to the current thread or greenlet.    This is literally the purpose of the threading.local() in this case.     Openstack applications like Keystone use this pattern with great success.

I should note that some openstack applications like Nova pass around the context explicitly to all their methods, while others like Keystone do use a threading.local().   Passing the context explicitly like Nova does might be a better way for you to go as it is likely easier to understand and debug.

> So a new thread.local and new connection per REST call doesn't seem to be very bad. 

when you create the threading local, e.g. the context, inside the "get_connection()" method and give that to the enginefacade as the context to use, you don't have a "new connection per REST call."   You will have, a "new connection/transaction **per function** per REST call".  That is, if your REST call calls method A, which calls method B, which calls method C, and all three of them make use of enginefacade.<something>.connection with this particular scheme, it means you will use *three* connections and transactions for your single REST call.   Additionally, if method A makes some changes to the database and then calls method B, method B  because it is not present in the same transaction as that of A will not see any of the pending changes that A has made.  In the worst case, method B or C will do something in their own transaction that deadlocks against what method A was doing, and your application crashes.    This was the pattern that was prevalent in Openstack before the new enginefacade pattern was added and issues like these happened all the time.

The pattern that enginefacade is trying to solve is that of methods which need to use a database and run inside of a transaction, which may be called by other methods that are already doing this, or not.   The kind of logic we are going for, in an expanded way, looks like this:

def method_a(self, sess=None):
    if sess is None:
        needs_commit=True
        sess = Session(bind=engine)
    else:
        needs_commit=False

    data = self.method_b(sess)
    if needs_commit:
        sess.commit()


def method_b(self, sess=None):
    if sess is None:
        needs_commit=True
        sess = Session(bind=engine)
    else:
        needs_commit=False

    data = self.method_c(sess)
    if needs_commit:
        sess.commit()
    return data

def method_c(self, sess=None):
    if sess is None:
        needs_commit=True
        sess = Session(bind=engine)
    else:
        needs_commit=False

    data = sess.query(data)...
    if needs_commit:
        sess.commit()
    return data

the above code is really hard to read and write (and test).  the idea is that you can call each method alone, and it will create its own transaction and commit it, but if you call another method that calls down to another one, it will instead participate in that ongoing transaction, rather than making its own connection/transaction which is both expensive and conflicting.

the enginefacade is there so that code which works like the above code can be written in a succinct style where all the transaction boundaries and failure mode handling can be done in a consistent and well-tested way.   it relies upon a shared context in order to maintain state between functions that are calling each other.    how this context is shared however is determined by the application, and the two options are generally "use a threadlocal" or "pass the context between methods".  

if you want to get rid of the threading.local(), you need to use a context object and all your methods must accept it and pass it along to others.  This is the pattern normally used like you can see here in nova:  https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L524   The context comes from oslo.context: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/context.py#L80.   on the other hand, Keystone uses enginefacade with the threading local, where they create it here: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/sql/core.py#L278  and you can see it in use (or not, since it's invisible) here: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/credential/backends/sql.py#L76

I think using the threading.local() shouldn't be any problem (Keystone at least does), but I understand it can be a little spooky, so since a lot of the openstack services don't use it, you may want to move towards explicit context object that you pass to all your service methods.   take a look at what nova is doing, Neutron also uses a context object but is more difficult to follow.

Done - Thank you for the comment.

Here's another reason to get rid of the 'if' here (and in the other functions below).  If the dict returned by the call is empty, "if api_reply" will be false, and you'll return None (the default return value) instead of an empty dict, which could make a difference to whatever is calling this function. neutron/objects/qos/policy.py.message: Can you explain why this is no longer needed?  This code enables the rolling upgrade behavior for QosPolicyRBAC objects.  Will there never ever be a reason for compatibility between versions of this object?  Given that there are already multiple versions that seems unlikely.  And there's not enough information in the commit message to know why you want to compel this behaior... but it is expected that any OVO object be able to downgrade to an older version if needed.  So I'd be very interested in getting an explanation, ideally for posterity in the commit message.

For sure and if you agree with this explanation, I'll add this to the commit message.

As you know the compatibility methods are meant to solve the problems between servers and agents with different code versions. OpenStack should keep 1 release backwards compatibility. What I'm removing are OVO versions backwards compatibility methods implemented more than 1 year ago because neither the server nor the agents should implement OVOs with versions older than the latest one.

Last changes affecting to object compatibility, done in those OVOs:
* QoSPolicy: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/428304/, 2 years ago.
* QosBandwidthLimitRule: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/449831/, 2y 1m ago
* QosDscpMarkingRule: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/300501/, 2y 10m ago
* QosMinimumBandwidthRule: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/344145/, 2y 8m ago
* QosRuleType: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/475260/, 1y 10m ago

I don't mind doing this - it's good housecleaning.  I don't think I would tear down the structure for making the checks as well as the checks themselves.  Perhaps leave obj_make_compatible in place with just a pass, so that in the future if there is a revision it is clear where compatibility code should be introduced.  You could even point at this change in a comment there as well, to help later engineers.

I'll propose a topic for the coming Neutron Team Meeting to propose that we make this kind of cleaning global.  That also vets the idea with the whole community, so others won't have the same questions I did.

Thanks!

Ok, we can avoid an additional parameter for a boolean that we use to generate the condition, however looking at the ceph-ansible code they should expect 3 params:

```
ceph_docker_registry_auth: (true|false)
ceph_docker_registry_username: ""
ceph_docker_registry_password: ""

```
So we still need a boolean and pass it to the playbook.
As you suggested, I'll try to embed the boolean in the json parameter (CephAuthRegistryParams) and simplify this structure!

This check over the expected parameters allow us to set the condition according to the CephAuthRegistry (line 265) and verifying (if CephAuthRegistry it's true) the user doesn't provide an empty string on both username and password: getting  an empty string would let the c-a playbook fail on `docker login command`[1], while evaluating username and password at this stage allow us to set the condition accordingly, undefine these variables (lines 535-546) and let ceph-ansible fail on the related validation task [2].
I'm testing this patch here[3], but we can plan to move it here if helps.

Often the user will have already set something like the following so can we have an option for this parameter to get the username/password from it? It doesn't seem good to require them to hardcode their username/password twice.

So I think the evaluation flow is right, and I'm going to turn this parameter:

```
CephAuthRegistryParams:
   description: The username and password used to authenticate on the
                 registry to pull ceph containers
    type: json
    default: {}
```

into:

```
ContainerImageRegistryCredentials:
    description: The username and password used to authenticate on the
                 registry to pull ceph containers
    type: json
    default: {}
```

In this way we can keep the same json structure provided by the "container image prepare" flow and process it accordingly.

Well this is interesting. On py3, this follows the IOError path :-/

 $ for p in python2 python3; do $p -c 'import errno; print(isinstance(OSError(errno.EACCES, "message"), IOError))'; done
 False

Yeah, that sounds like a good plan to me.

Indeed that test looks redundant. We only care about the errno value and EACCES is already tested.

A test for the failure to open the lock file as you suggest would be better.

As for the fcntl module: py2 raises an IOError on failures.
the fcntl module doc for py3 says:

"Changed in version 3.3: Operations in this module used to raise an IOError where they now raise an OSError."

Which is a little misleading. It raises a "BlockingIOError", which is a subclass of OSError/IOError.

So in practice, catching IOError is still fine with py3. But, since what we really care about is errno, should we catch (OSError, IOError) to be safe if the behavior ever changes? If so it should also be done in common/utils.py:lock_file() where there's the same situation. Let me know you what you think is best for this case, and I'll update the patch

pkg/document/bundle.go.message:
Upstream kubernetes is using kustomize v2.0.3 right now. I think version 3 breaks dependencies to client-go, in particular, it references older version of client-go v11, which in turn depends on wrong apimachinery version. So if you try to import a controller-runtime, 	"k8s.io/kubectl/pkg/cmd/apply", or any other libraries built on top of client-go, import fails, because of wrong functions calls, of v11 client-go. 

Maybe there is a an easy fix to that, but so far, i have failed to find one. So i would suggest using 2.0.3 kustomize, as in kubernetes upstream, unless i am missing something, and there is easy fix for that.

Oh, good point.  Maybe we could include that patch and create another lp stating that we may loose time using import vs include and that maybe using include + tag always is a superior solution timewise (as most of tasks have the step conditional).

In any case, whatever we end up choosing we should be strive for consistancy.  Currently we have a mixed bag of include_role and import_role, with import_role being mostly used.  the include are not always required (no loop) so I'm not sure we have a clear policy here, unless I missed something.

This will considerably slow down execution, because it will import always, and apply the conditional in line 119-120 to all tasks it imports.

Perhaps a better way to achieve the same goal here would be to use include_role, but with the always tag on the task. That way it will always evaluate the task for any tag spec, but it will only execute the include when the condition is met.
or we could move the step == 1 check into a jinja

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message:
Why would you need to do this? The 

(not wipe_ceph_osds | type_debug == 'bool') should do the trick

Place the following test code at the beginning of your main playbook/test playbook and run it, run it again with wipe_ceph_osds set to "true"/"false"

  - set_fact:
      wipe_ceph_osds: abc

  - name: Check for Ceph data wipe flag
    fail:
      msg: "wipe_ceph_osds is misconfigured. Valid value is either 'true' or 'false'"
    when: not wipe_ceph_osds|type_debug == 'bool'

  - meta: end_play

you can also try moving the not out of the parentheses 
  when: not (wipe_ceph_osds|type == 'bool')

I just tested and it worked unless the parameter is overwritten via --extra-vars option. Now I see the reason for this funky code. Please add a comment regarding Ansible's mishandling of boolean input via --extra-vars. Will revisit these types of check when we upversion Ansible.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/resto.message: Same comment as change in bootstrap playbook

this config parameter is already validated in bootstrap playbook, which is run before this role, as boolean value, you don't need to use the bool filter here. Same comment applies to other instances in this file.

when: not wipe_ceph_osds

Yes it is validated here, yet it's not enough. Problem is that, when bools are passed as extra args at cli, they are parsed as strings. So, wipe_ceph_osds=true will always be a string (issue described in https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/17193) as a workaround user can pass a dictionary {wipe_ceph_osds: true} yet this doesn't feel right as all the other arguments are passed with equal and it will be awkward to make user pass a dictionary so solution is to also check for 'true' and 'false'.

One more issue caused by this is that at restore we create a flag file to mark that restore is in progress and, when code aborts in the bootstrap, this flag is left behind and user is unable to rerun the restore (although nothing critical has been done). So I added one more check at the beginning of restore before the flag is created.

Therefore we now have two checks, both are needed as some parts of the code are run only at bootstrap and other parts at restore (and this is not a functional programming language :) ).

Oh, and I tried to remove the flag file using a block and a rescue statement but there are missing variables in the bootstrap to do a proper cleanup. Therefore I did not find any way to avoid the double check.

Something changed in the networking area with the last rebase and unlocking controller-0 failed (when booting a system MGMT ip is configured AFTER drbd is started). This is a fix for the issue.

Before using sed I tried with lineinfile and blockinfile but w/o any luck. Problem is that lineinfile doesn't allow conditional replacing of multiple lines so had to fall back to awk (we need both 127.0.0.1 AND 127.0.0.2 configured).
Seems reasonable. So I guess we don't know what or why this behavior changed? But since you tested this and didn't see any issues, I guess refeverting to this behavior didn't have any impacts

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/recov.message: Looks like this flag is never removed - is that an issue?

It's by design. The flag is needed and removed by sysinv once controller-1 becomes 'available'.

It is needed by sysinv to answer when asked if a node should or should not wipe the OSDs.

See changes and comment in: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681727/2/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controllers/v1/host.py

The one asking for this is the Anaconda installer, which takes care of disk wipes. See: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681728/3/bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_common.cfg

The idea is that during B&R, if user selects the -e "wipe_ceph_osds=false" option when Ansible restore playbook is executed we skip OSD wipe on controller-1. That's why we create the flag. But then sysinv is the one in charge of it.
